explanation: based on the provided data, planting peaches appears to be the most profitable option. the average peach yield in california is 13.7 tons per acre with an average price of $763 per ton. over 10 acres, this would result in an expected yield of 137 tons and an expected revenue of $104,531 (137 tons * $763 per ton). in comparison, grapefruit has an average yield of 457 boxes per acre and an average price of $24.33 per box, which would result in an expected revenue of $111,051 (457 boxes/acre * 10 acres * $24.33 per box). however, grapefruit production has been significantly affected by winter storm uri and citrus greening disease, leading to lower production levels and increased reliance on imports, which could introduce more risk and potential for lower yields than the average. lemons have an average yield of 428 boxes per acre and an average price of $23.3 per box, resulting in an expected revenue of $99,804 (428 boxes/acre * 10 acres * $23.3 per box), but lemon production is at its lowest in five years due to heat damage, which also adds risk to the expected yield. peaches, on the other hand, are forecasted to have the largest crop since 2017, and despite a 3 percent decrease forecast for processing clingstone peaches, the overall increase in production and the higher expected yield make peaches the recommended choice for maximizing profit on your 10 acres of land.
